quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping as an alternative to unicorn chasing
quotes.text: The reason I think it's great for entrepreneurs to start bootstrapping is because they just have more practice making money, and they get better, and better, and better at the fundamental skill you need to have ultimately to run a successful business, which is to make money.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Frames bootstrapping as deliberate practice in the core business skill—revenue generation—rather than a funding strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping as an alternative to unicorn chasing
quotes.text: What I'm saying is, this is a way to be. It's an alternative to what you're often hearing in our industry, which is, "Go big or go home. Raise a bunch of money and get huge, and unicorn status," and the whole thing.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Positions bootstrapping as a legitimate operating model that counters the default “raise and scale” narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping as an alternative to unicorn chasing
quotes.text: Just know though that basically almost nobody makes it that way. Really, almost nobody really makes it that way, and there's a lot more room to make it, and to build a successful business, if you throw out that outlier and look at all the other places you can land as a business.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Highlights the low probability of unicorn outcomes and encourages aiming for a wider set of viable business endpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping as an alternative to unicorn chasing
quotes.text: They have no investors, no board. They have no plans to go public. They never want to sell their business. They've made a profit for 24 years in a row.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of a long-term, profitable company built outside the VC/exit treadmill.

quotes.topic_title: Bootstrapping as an alternative to unicorn chasing
quotes.text: All of this profit filters down to the founders and employees because they have no investors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the ownership/compensation implication of bootstrapping: profits accrue to the people building the company.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They have no investors, no board. They have no plans to go public. They never want to sell their business.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete alternative company model that challenges the default VC-backed path and clarifies what “independence” can look like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They've made a profit for 24 years in a row.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific performance data point that underscores the viability of long-term profitability without venture funding.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: All of this profit filters down to the founders and employees because they have no investors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical incentive/ownership insight about how capitalization choices directly affect who benefits from success.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But it's also important to know that there is a different option available, and it can be much more fulfilling and fun, and even much more lucrative, by bootstrapping your idea.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable advice encouraging founders to explicitly consider bootstrapping as a potentially superior path on multiple dimensions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: we get into why constraints like small teams and less cash often lead to better outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive operating principle that reframes constraints as a lever for better execution and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single tool to manage multiple recurring workflows (content, interviews, sponsorships).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Within that post, they shared a dozen templates that they use internally to run their product team, including managing the roadmap, their OKR process, getting internal feedback.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Highlights a reusable methodology—standardized templates—for core product operations like roadmaps and OKRs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets, and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic: tool sprawl is a signal to consolidate work into a single system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career, and something that worked really well for me a few years ago, is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Memorable career framework: build a “personal board of directors” to accelerate decisions and growth through trusted peers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Jason Feifer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: treat peer-group building as something you can shortcut intentionally rather than leaving to chance over years.

quotes.topic_title: 37signals scale: profits, customers, and focus
quotes.text: We don't talk about things that don't really matter so much, like revenues don't really matter 'cause you can go broke generating a lot of money. But, we talk about profits.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Reframes what to measure and optimize for—profitability over revenue—as a practical operating principle.

quotes.topic_title: 37signals scale: profits, customers, and focus
quotes.text: Historically, let's say over the past 10 years or so, we've been profitable every year for 24 years. But let's say over the last 10 years, we've been doing double-digit million dollar profits on an annual basis, which is really nice.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Concrete proof point that long-term, consistent profitability at meaningful scale is possible without chasing typical startup narratives.

quotes.topic_title: 37signals scale: profits, customers, and focus
quotes.text: We have about a 100,000 plus paying customers, so that's a rough number, and we've about currently 75 or so employees.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Specific scale metrics that illustrate a small-team, high-leverage model practitioners can benchmark against.

quotes.topic_title: 37signals scale: profits, customers, and focus
quotes.text: We just want to make more money than we spend, have good healthy margins which allow us to experiment, and play, and not be afraid to do things that may not work, and just enjoy ourselves.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A simple financial framework: margins buy optionality, enabling experimentation and resilience without external pressure.

quotes.topic_title: When raising money makes sense
quotes.text: Obviously, if you're building cars, or you need a factory, or you're opening a restaurant and there's actual things you need to buy like ovens, and you need to hire people right off the bat, and you need to pay rent, you need capital.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A practical rule-of-thumb: raise money when your business has unavoidable upfront capital expenditures.

quotes.topic_title: When raising money makes sense
quotes.text: Software businesses though, and businesses like ours, we just make software, and a lot of people in our industry are like us in that respect. They need a couple laptops and a couple people, and it's pretty cheap. It's really pretty cheap to get going, and the margins are incredibly healthy in software, or they should be.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Contrasts capital-intensive businesses with software to argue many software startups can bootstrap due to low startup costs and high margins.

quotes.topic_title: When raising money makes sense
quotes.text: What's interesting is that Silicon Valley has found a way to make the most profitable style of business the least profitable.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A counterintuitive critique that challenges the assumption that venture-backed software companies naturally become highly profitable.

quotes.topic_title: When raising money makes sense
quotes.text: I think it actually hurts you if you go out and think that you do, because there really is only one outcome for venture-backed companies, which is go huge.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Warns that venture funding imposes a single strategic path—hypergrowth—which can be misaligned with many viable businesses.

quotes.topic_title: When raising money makes sense
quotes.text: If you think about all of the space between a small business and a massive, huge unicorn-y business, there's so much room there that you could normally find your own way, and slide into a slot or a place that makes sense for you. But if you're venture-backed, you just don't even have the opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model of the “middle space” of sustainable outcomes that venture incentives often eliminate.

quotes.topic_title: Why small teams can beat big competitors
quotes.text: We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. They're focused on growth.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A clear strategic tradeoff that explains how small teams can outperform larger competitors by optimizing for efficiency over headcount-driven growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why small teams can beat big competitors
quotes.text: Nobody can pay us more than 300 bucks. I don't care how big your company is, the most you can pay us is $299, you get unlimited users.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A concrete pricing constraint that forces product simplicity and prevents enterprise-driven complexity from creeping into the business.

quotes.topic_title: Why small teams can beat big competitors
quotes.text: We build products with two people at a time. So every feature we work on in Basecamp, or HEY, or whatever we're building is two people, one programmer, one designer, and they have a maximum of six weeks to deliver the feature that they're working on.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A lightweight delivery methodology (two-person teams + six-week max) that reduces coordination overhead and keeps projects from ballooning.

quotes.topic_title: Why small teams can beat big competitors
quotes.text: But to spend money because you have it on things you don't need is something that Silicon Valley's gotten quite good at, but we're quite bad at intentionally. I don't want to spend money on things we don't need.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A contrarian stance on hiring/spend discipline that practitioners can apply to resist unnecessary scaling and preserve focus.

quotes.topic_title: Why small teams can beat big competitors
quotes.text: Honestly, if you gave me 1,000 people, I wouldn't know what to do with them. We would fall apart.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A memorable warning that beyond a certain size, organizational complexity can overwhelm execution rather than improve it.

quotes.topic_title: Defining success: enjoyment, profit, and simplicity
quotes.text: For me, it's really about, would I want to do this again? If the answer is, "Yeah, that was enjoyable. I enjoyed that. That was worthwhile. I'm glad I did that. I'd like to do that again," then it was successful.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable litmus test for defining success based on whether the work is worth repeating.

quotes.topic_title: Defining success: enjoyment, profit, and simplicity
quotes.text: It's in total, collectively, are we making more money than we spend? That's the only thing we ultimately look at, whether or not this product is more profitable than that product, and this is behind that, it's all the things we do.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A counterintuitive profitability model that focuses on overall sustainability rather than per-product optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Defining success: enjoyment, profit, and simplicity
quotes.text: What is the value of saying thank you to somebody? Would you want to A/B test that and, if it turned out that it was worse to say thank you to somebody, would you not do that? No, you would do it because it's still the right thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A principled decision-making rule: don’t let metrics override basic decency and good judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Defining success: enjoyment, profit, and simplicity
quotes.text: We don't have financial goals. We don't have OKRs or KPIs. I don't have revenue targets. I don't have growth targets, in terms of the number of customers we need to pick up this year versus last year. I don't look at any of those things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A direct rejection of conventional goal-setting systems in favor of simpler, values-driven operations.

quotes.topic_title: Defining success: enjoyment, profit, and simplicity
quotes.text: It's just, at the end, "Did we make more than we spend? We did. Then the things we did this year were worth it." That's how it goes.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A minimalist annual evaluation method that practitioners can apply as a sanity check for business decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Playing the infinite game: staying independent
quotes.text: I feel like I have the exact same job as I did when I was 15, that this is a long continuum of finding stuff that I like.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Reframes entrepreneurship as a long-term continuum of doing work you enjoy, rather than a series of disconnected ventures.

quotes.topic_title: Playing the infinite game: staying independent
quotes.text: This is my job, so I want to create the company that I want to work at, and I want to keep doing this job for as long as I can.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Actionable lens for company-building: design the business around the work and environment you want to sustain long-term.

quotes.topic_title: Playing the infinite game: staying independent
quotes.text: So to get in bed with an investment that would say, "In five years you have to stop doing what you're doing, you're going to get a big paycheck maybe, but you got to stop doing what you're doing because we're going to sell this business, and you're going to have to go work for this other company for two years and do their thing. Then eventually, after that's over, you'll leave and you'll go start another thing," that just has no appeal to me at all.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Counterintuitive critique of venture incentives: funding can force an endpoint and unwanted career constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Playing the infinite game: staying independent
quotes.text: What's cool about having a company like ours, which is an independent business, we don't have to ask anyone for permission. No one can tell us no.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Highlights independence as a practical operating advantage—faster decisions and broader strategic freedom.

quotes.topic_title: Playing the infinite game: staying independent
quotes.text: So we can turn this into anything we want. It's this vehicle, more so than it is a software business.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: treat the company as a flexible vehicle for evolving work, not a fixed product category.

quotes.topic_title: Startups vs. stay-ups and enduring plateaus
quotes.text: Because, frankly, starting a business is actually way easier than staying in business.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that shifts focus from launching to the harder work of long-term endurance.

quotes.topic_title: Startups vs. stay-ups and enduring plateaus
quotes.text: But, are you going to be there in two years? Are you going to be there in five years when competition rushes in? When you have employees, are you going to be there? Staying is harder than starting.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A practical durability test for founders to evaluate whether their business can survive time, competition, and team complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Startups vs. stay-ups and enduring plateaus
quotes.text: Then it's like, "Well, do you want to keep doing this? Or, are you just high on the growth? Or, do you actually like the thing?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A diagnostic set of questions to determine whether motivation is sustainable beyond early growth.

quotes.topic_title: Startups vs. stay-ups and enduring plateaus
quotes.text: If you want to do the thing for a long period of time, you've got to like the thing because you're going to have to endure these moments of plateaus, which is what staying up is all about.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A mental model for long-term creators/operators: plateaus are normal, so enjoyment of the work is a prerequisite for persistence.

quotes.topic_title: Startups vs. stay-ups and enduring plateaus
quotes.text: We've had wavy years, always been profitable, but our profit's different every year. Sometimes it's more, and sometimes it's less. Sometimes our margin is more, sometimes it's less.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A concrete example that normalizes variability while emphasizing profitability as the enduring baseline.

quotes.topic_title: Longevity, motivation cycles, and leadership curiosity
quotes.text: I'm trying to be very conscious of my energy interest. Right now, I'm getting energy from the business. There are times in the past where the business sapped energy for me. If it SAPs too much, at some point, you start to think, "Is it worth it? Do I want to keep doing this?" Right now, I'm fueled again by it. But, I don't know what it'll be like in a year from now. I really don't know. I think I'm more conscious of that than I've ever been given how long I've been doing this.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A practical self-management framework: monitor whether the business is energizing or draining you and use that as an input to decisions about continuing.

quotes.topic_title: Longevity, motivation cycles, and leadership curiosity
quotes.text: Also, I always have this strange fantasy, I'm always curious, "What would someone else do with this place? What if someone else could just step in tomorrow? How would they run it? No one's ever had a chance to run it but me. What would they do differently?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A leadership thought exercise for spotting blind spots: imagine a new operator taking over and identify what they’d change.

quotes.topic_title: Longevity, motivation cycles, and leadership curiosity
quotes.text: What if we spent 70% of our margin on growth? What would that look like?
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A concrete counterfactual to pressure-test your strategy by exploring an extreme growth tradeoff and its implications.

quotes.topic_title: Longevity, motivation cycles, and leadership curiosity
quotes.text: I'm not really thinking about all the things we could do. I'm thinking about what we're doing. So I think someone else would come in and think about the things we could do.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A focus principle that challenges conventional “maximize opportunities” thinking by prioritizing current commitments over option expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Longevity, motivation cycles, and leadership curiosity
quotes.text: You can't really A/B test an entire company. I'd seek to A/B test small things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A pragmatic methodology for experimentation: accept that strategy-level tests are hard and instead run smaller, testable experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Who should bootstrap vs. pursue venture scale
quotes.text: But let's face it, those are extreme outliers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Reframes venture-scale success as statistically rare, pushing founders to calibrate expectations and strategy accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Who should bootstrap vs. pursue venture scale
quotes.text: The majority of companies on this planet run like ours. They're bootstrapped, they don't have any money. No one's willing to give them a penny and they open up a shop somewhere, they do something, they put their shingle out and they launch a website or whatever and they try to make it work.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Grounds the bootstrap path as the default reality for most businesses, not an edge-case, which can guide more practical planning.

quotes.topic_title: Who should bootstrap vs. pursue venture scale
quotes.text: I got to make more money than I spend otherwise I'm out. I don't have this big cushion of millions sitting in the bank that I can just spend on things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A simple operational rule-of-thumb that emphasizes sustainability, cost discipline, and survival constraints without funding.

quotes.topic_title: Who should bootstrap vs. pursue venture scale
quotes.text: So my interest is optionality. If I could land in 135 different positions and have a sustainable business, that's great. Versus saying there's only one way I'm going to be successful or happy.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Introduces “optionality” as a decision framework: maximize viable landing spots instead of betting everything on a single outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Who should bootstrap vs. pursue venture scale
quotes.text: Meanwhile, there are hundreds or thousands of slots for other kinds of companies to make it if they don't go for the moon.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Highlights an alternative opportunity landscape—more attainable paths exist than moonshots—encouraging founders to broaden success criteria.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a business truly venture-scale
quotes.text: So it's more of a mindset, what are you after?
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Reframes “venture-scale” as a strategic intent and operating philosophy, not an inherent property of the product.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a business truly venture-scale
quotes.text: There's things like Airbnb is a great example that that has to have a certain degree of scale to really be something that no matter where you go in the world, you're like, I can get an Airbnb there. And that's probably going to take money to get there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Gives a concrete test for when venture funding is structurally necessary: trust and usefulness depend on rapid, broad physical-world availability.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a business truly venture-scale
quotes.text: Well, you have to know that there's going to be one to begin to trust us. So in order to do that, you have to expand rapidly.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mechanism (trust via ubiquity) that forces certain marketplaces/logistics businesses into blitz-scaling.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a business truly venture-scale
quotes.text: Airbnb's a physical product, Uber's a physical product, Basecamp, Monday, Asana, they're available everywhere instantly anyway. I don't know what you need the money for other than marketing.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Contrasts physical-network businesses vs. software distribution, arguing many software companies don’t need venture capital beyond marketing spend.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a business truly venture-scale
quotes.text: And it's interesting because marketing's losing them a lot of money.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Calls out a common venture-backed tradeoff: growth marketing can be the primary driver of unprofitability.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up: appetites, six-week cycles, two-person teams
quotes.text: That whatever we choose to do can take no longer than six weeks. So this is not an estimate of time, it's an appetite, which is a radically different approach.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Introduces the core Shape Up mental model of fixed time budgets (“appetites”) instead of unreliable estimates.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up: appetites, six-week cycles, two-person teams
quotes.text: Work expands to fill the time available. So for us it's about appetite.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A counterintuitive rationale for why setting a hard timebox changes behavior and keeps projects from ballooning.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up: appetites, six-week cycles, two-person teams
quotes.text: We don't have a spec, we don't create to-dos or tasks or tickets for people. They create the work that needs to get done to fulfill the idea that we've written up and designed essentially, and they figure out how to do it.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Describes an autonomy-first execution model where teams define tasks themselves rather than being managed via tickets.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up: appetites, six-week cycles, two-person teams
quotes.text: So in most cases it should die, meaning it just doesn't happen.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A hardline policy that preserves the integrity of timeboxing by killing work that can’t fit the appetite.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up: appetites, six-week cycles, two-person teams
quotes.text: This prevents long running projects that never end, which by the way are the most demoralizing kinds of projects.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Connects the methodology to a practical outcome: avoiding morale-destroying projects that drag on indefinitely.

quotes.topic_title: No promises, and how to adopt new methods safely
quotes.text: Promises are the downfall of every business.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that making delivery promises can create avoidable failure modes and disappointment.

quotes.topic_title: No promises, and how to adopt new methods safely
quotes.text: And by the way, the worst promise, and by the way, we've made a couple of these recently, we always regret them. It's like by the end of the year. That's the one promise you got to be very careful of, because it's so easy to make. There's nothing easier than promising work later.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A specific anti-pattern (“by end of year”) practitioners can watch for to avoid low-accountability commitments that backfire.

quotes.topic_title: No promises, and how to adopt new methods safely
quotes.text: So what we often encourage people to do is keep working the way you're working, but some future project, some low criticality project, try this new method on that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A practical rollout strategy: pilot new process changes on low-stakes work to reduce organizational risk.

quotes.topic_title: No promises, and how to adopt new methods safely
quotes.text: So go pick some things that don't matter if you suck at them for a while and try this method over there and go, oh, you know what? I'm actually getting quite good. Now let's try to bring this into some more critical stuff.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A learning model that normalizes early incompetence and prescribes a staged adoption path from low- to high-criticality projects.

quotes.topic_title: No promises, and how to adopt new methods safely
quotes.text: Because what ends up happening is that when people try to try something new on something really critical and it doesn't work, they'll never try it again.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A cautionary observation about how a failed high-stakes experiment can permanently poison future process change.

quotes.topic_title: Why they avoid 'sprints' and use cooldowns
quotes.text: No, I hate that term. I don't like the word sprint because how do you feel after a sprint? Exhausted.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Reframes “sprints” as a harmful metaphor that bakes in burnout and unsustainable pace.

quotes.topic_title: Why they avoid 'sprints' and use cooldowns
quotes.text: And that's why I don't like the word because you can't layer that back to back to back to back. You cannot sprint back to back, to back, to back in life. And you can't do it at work.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: A practical warning against stacking intense delivery cycles without recovery time.

quotes.topic_title: Why they avoid 'sprints' and use cooldowns
quotes.text: So what we do is after our six week cycles, we typically take what we call a two-week cool down. So we call these cycles, not sprints.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Provides a concrete operating cadence (6-week cycles + 2-week cooldown) teams can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Why they avoid 'sprints' and use cooldowns
quotes.text: So we call them cycles because cycles happen again and again and again. Sprints start and end. Cycles happen.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model shift from one-off bursts to repeatable, sustainable rhythms.

quotes.topic_title: Why they avoid 'sprints' and use cooldowns
quotes.text: It's not that you're stopping work, it's that you're doing other kinds of work. And that I think is replenishing and refreshing, and I think that's the important part versus back to back to back sprints of the same kind of work all the time.
quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.context: Clarifies how cooldowns work in practice: switch to cleanup and exploratory tasks to restore energy without halting progress.
